episode.title: Louisiana ex rel. Gremillion v. NAACP

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 294, Louisiana ex rel. Jack P.F. Gremillion, Attorney General, et al., Appellants, versus N.A.A.C.P. et al.
Mr. Schuler.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and Associate Justices.
The matter reached as this Court today on appeal from the Eastern District Court for the State of Louisiana.
A three-judge court in that proceeding held unconstitutional, two laws of the State of Louisiana and enjoined the enforcement of those statutes.
And so under the provisions of 28 U.S.C.1253, this matter was appealed directly to this Court.
Actually, this matter involves two separate lawsuits which were consolidated for trial in the court below.
The first lawsuit was filed in March of 1956 in the Nineteenth Judicial District State Court.

That suit was a suit by the former Attorney General which sought to enjoin the N.A.A.C.P. and its affiliates in doing business in the State because they had failed and neglected to file a membership and officer list which was required by statute of the State of Louisiana, passed in 1924.
This --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: 19 when?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Now, this suit was filed on March 1st, 1956 and 28 days later, the defendants therein, the N.A.A.C.P. and various individuals went in the federal court and moved that the said suit be removed to the federal court.
The federal courts on the removal of the petition and the case remained pending or I should say dormant, on the docket of that court now.

In 1958, November thereof, there was a new suit filed in the Eastern District of the State of Louisiana by the New Orleans branch of the N.A.A.C.P. seeking to have the constitutionality of Act 20 -- Act 2 of 1924 and Act 260 of 1958, declared unconstitutional and have the enforcement thereof enjoined by the court.

These two cases were consolidated at the trial and heard by a three-judge court and the three-judge court rendered an opinion in February 29th of 1960, holding that these two statutes were unconstitutional.
The first statute that is the membership list statute on the basis that it conflicted with the First Amendment as interpreted by the N.A.A.C.P. versus Alabama and Bates versus Little Rock cases.

The second statute, a Communist affidavit statute, I -- they held it was in conflict with the Due Process Clause of United States Constitution and that it provided for a filing of something which would've be impossible to be within the knowledge of the persons required to file it.
Notice of appeal in this matter was filed in April 25th, 1960 and this Court noted the probable jurisdiction on the 24th day of October, 1960.

Actually, the primary question involved herein today, is a clash, conflict between the State's police power and between the provisions of the First Amendment of United States Constitution as interpreted by this Court.
The freedom of association doctrine, while never so --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Would you -- I wonder if it troubles you, before you get in to the legal discussion of the State for some particularity.
What it is?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: When we (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What it is with reference to which illegal doctrines have to be applied?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I don't quite follow the question, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What are the facts of this case?
Are there any facts or just an abstract legal question?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, there are some facts that are agreed upon, others that are in dispute.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It makes all the more important (Inaudible) to have them, I should think.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: The facts are that in 1924, the State of Louisiana enacted a statute known as a membership registration statute.
Your Honors are all familiar with the Bryant versus Zimmerman case.
Our statute is very similar to the New York statute in that case.

It provides that each -- once each year, the organizations or corporations doing business in the State of Louisiana other than business corporations, must file with the Secretary of State a list of the members of the corporation as well as a list of the officers and addresses of the officers of the corporation or association.
The second statute involved herein was passed in 1958.

It is a statute which requires all affiliates within the State that have parent organizations outside the State, to have filed with the State and the Secretary of State, an affidavit to the effect that none of the officers of the parent corporation are members of the Communist Party or members of any organization, to create subversive by the Attorney General of the United States.
Now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Under the first statute, Mr. Schuler, under the first statute --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- are the required reports filed by organizations.
Have they been through 34?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: No, sir.
They have not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean nobody has paid any attention to this statute?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: They did not and I can't find any record of any being filed until about 1956, when this statute was brought into (b) -- was enforced.
Now, since that time, we have some 2000 organizations in the State that are complying with the requirements of filing a membership list.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Does the record show that how it was brought into being as you call it (Voice Overlap) the attorneys of then Attorney Generals is safe for now and I'm going to enforce this and everybody should obey it?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, that is correct.
It does not show what the then Attorney General did, but the suit was filed three months later, the present Attorney General took office and he served notice upon all organizations.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Suit against who was filed?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: The N.A.A.C.P. and the present Attorney General served notice upon all organizations in the State that he would prosecute them if they would not comply with the requirements of this statute and there's -- he has an affidavit in the record which reflects this and he specifically points out various organizations which he told either to file or he would file a suit against them, which resulted either in their filing a membership list or in their disbanding the organization.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You said, 2000?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Yes, sir.
There -- the statement --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where is that?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: You will find on page 129 and 130, an affidavit by the Secretary of State showing the number of organizations which filed the membership list.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And the record anyway shows what kind of organizations they are?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: No, sir.
It does not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Are they all incorporated, or a -- a membership organizations --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: You Honor, they're -- actually, there's no way of telling under the laws of our State.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The odd fellows have to file one of alliance or the --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor, Garden Clubs

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I noticed there's a great drought from 1958 of -- in 1958 to 1959, a number of filings have cut into half.
From 1957 to 1958 was cut into half.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: The --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Well, 1959 Your Honor would not really reflect anything because the period of time, the 15-day period within which the applications or the membership list had to be filed, was not yet completed at that time.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I mean 1957 to 1958, two full years.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.
There was a dropped, but I have no explanation.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Because I was interrupting you, you may (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That's perfectly alright.
Now, I believe at the present time, are there any factual situations that are not quite clear?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, what -- about what facts is their dispute?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Actually, the only real dispute in fact, is whether or not there were economic reprisals against members of the N.A.A.C.P. whose names were revealed by the publication of this membership list.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did they file the untold list, did they file it?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Yes, sir.
Some --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What is it -- what is the suit about then that they shouldn't be required to file them in the future?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, they filed them -- some of their organizations within the State filed them for two-year periods.
Since 1958, they have refused to file the list with the State basing their contention upon the N.A.A.C.P. versus Alabama case.
Of course, it's very curious to note that in every case where we show two consecutive years that an N.A.A.C.P. branch filed a list of its members.
It increased the second year over the first.
In other words, in New Orleans, they nearly tripled after they filed their first list.
In Lake Charles, they over doubled after filing their list.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Let's see if I understand it.
This was a dead letter until -- until the Attorney General in 1956 gave notice --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- fairly on this Court?
Were the filings made that year in 1956 for 1956, the next year, I'd suppose.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That's right.
There were some made in 1956, some in 1957 and I believe some in 1958.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Then came the decision of this Court and as a result of that, was it -- and one case result of that and at all events following that, N.A.A.C.P. has refused to file?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That is absolutely correct.
They've refused to file (Voice Overlap)--

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's -- that's (Inaudible), that is that suit.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.
A fact that particular proposition is actually in both suits.
The only --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, how many organizations identified with the N.A.A.C.P. are there (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: We have nowhere, none.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well -- well, you -- now you've said they didn't file any.
What you said, because I misunderstand you?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I said --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Filings by several different companies.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I said that several of the affiliates within the State did file membership lists.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, then, that -- in other words, the statute requires independent filings by each of the affiliates?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And how many affiliates in fact filed?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: In one year, we had as many as 11 filed.
On various years, it has gone from 1 or 2 to 11 and backed down to none.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You can't tell whether 11 is the total number of affiliates.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I would have to go outside the record, I know there are more.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And have they all quit all the affiliates?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: We have not had one affidavit or one membership list or officer list filed with the States as 1958.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: By any (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: By any affiliate of the N.A.A.C.P.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) laid on other than affiliate for the N.A.A.C.P. , your statute?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Oh, yes sir.
As I stated in --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No -- no.
I mean, are there any N.A.A.C.P. organizations besides the Louisiana affiliates?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: It would operate on the national, if they desire to do business in the State which they do.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So they would be required to file.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: They would be required --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What's their member list of -- membership list of --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Their membership list would only be of their members within the State.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Within the State.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And have they ever filed?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean they didn't file any -- the result of the 1956 announcement?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: No, sir.
Only certain affiliates within the State filed that list.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That is both?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I didn't --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The locals.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Yes, the certain locals or affiliates of the national body.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Women's advisory are -- something like Women's Advisory Committee obviously.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Well, I don't know what it's exactly like.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I don't either.
I'm just drawing out of the air.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: No, it's -- I guess what you might call sort of like a local union and a -- and a national.
It's an affiliate of the national body and follows a policy in constitution thereof.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You've referred to the Attorney General's announcement of it.
Where is that published in the record?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: On page 132, 133 and 134, an affidavit by the Attorney General.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is that the way all of this started?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where is that announcement that you're talking about?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: The Attorney General made it general and -- and just by conversations, by references in newspaper that he was going to enforce the law.
This affidavit in here is an affidavit by the Attorney General as to the means and methods he took to communicate his policy to the public at large.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What I'm interested in is in -- is there any statement in here that shows why he said he would decide it to enforce that law?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Of and I would say, it would be his duty.
It's his duty under the statute.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understand that but did -- did he make any statement about it?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: No, sir.
To the best of my knowledge, he did not.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, why -- what do you mean by the 1956 announcement then?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I did not.
I said if a suit was filed in 19 --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Several times -- several statements were made to the Attorney General, 1956 announcement.
Has -- was there any such announcement?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, as I say, it all depends on what you consider an announcement.

As I said, the Attorney General in his affidavits set forth that he made announcement generally to the public that he was intending to enforce the statute which under his -- under the laws setup, he was required to do.
He advised organizations for the fact that they would have to file a list.
I think the affidavit more than speaks for itself.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But I -- I -- all I was interested in was to see if you had that so-called 1956 announcement that the Attorney General made --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I believe, Your Honor --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) said why he had decided to enforce that it was -- was in here?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Schuler, when if -- if the 1956 -- the 1956, there was action taken by the then Attorney General Fred LeBlanc.
When did the present Attorney General enter office?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: May of 1956.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Oh, the suit was started by his predecessor --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- and continued it and then he -- so that the announcement really was what you would say the effective announcement by taking of -- by starting a litigation.
So far as the record shows that Justice Black had tried to elicit, there is no statement.
No, no release of whatever these modern terms are of talking.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Well, if -- if you're going to address it up into a formal statement --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But, I don't -- I don't --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I don't believe there is any such thing.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Either Justice Black nor I would dress up or dress down, I just want information.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, as I say, in the affidavit, the Attorney General sets forth the means by -- the means he took in order to inform the public of his intention to follow the laws of the State of Louisiana.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: We have your statement that an act passed in 1924 laid dead on the statute books of Louisiana.
Attorney General Fred S. LeBlanc started the suit in 1956, is that correct?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That is correct with one thing I'm not sure, whether or not, there was any compliance there would immediately in 1924.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Anyhow, we don't have a deal.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: It -- I can say with a -- a shortness that there was no compliance from 1950 until 1956.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I notice is that a newspaper or something in the record.
I suppose that's the most reliable evidence, but this is a newspaper dated January 5, 1957.
Its branches in New Orleans, Shreveport and Lake Charles, filed this earlier to comply with the 1924 state law requiring such rules to uphold that national garden church groups.
The old law, originally aimed at the ku klux klan was used last year to outlaw the pro immigration organization in the State.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Yet, I would say it was used to enjoin it from doing business because they failed and refused to file their list in conformance with the law.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think -- is -- is there any suggestion here that this old law was revived only to require the N.A.A.C.P. to file?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: It has been contended by the plaintiffs herein, however, I find nothing in the record to show that was the only reason and I would say that the evidence would belie that since as I say, the Attorney General has vigorously seen to it that other organizations within the State had to make equal compliance with the law as reflected by the organizations that have filed in accordance with that statute.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Schuler, may I ask you merely as a historical fact carrying no innuendo, just as a historical fact if it's an ascertainably historical fact.
Was the klan a lively organization in Louisiana between 1924 and 1930s?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I would say that the passage of this statute in 1924 sounded the death knell of the clan in the State as a real active organization after the statute had very rapidly passed out of the picture.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean the passage of the Act was so effective that --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- that called it out?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: It did.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Alright.
I'm not -- I'm -- [Laughs] you cannot imagine how ignorant I am of what took place in -- in Louisiana between 1924 and 1935 --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Oh, Your Honor, I'm --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: -- I'm rather ignorant too, I wasn't born then.[Laughter]

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, our knowledge were limited to the date of our birth, would be awfully ignorant, even more so than we are.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: May I ask you this?
Does the Act require all of the fraternal organizations --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: It does, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- to file every Masonic Lodge, every Knights of Columbus Lodge, every Elks Lodge, every --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, I would have extreme doubt with regard to the Knights of Columbus and the Masonic Temple Lodge, since they could very easily come under the definition of a religious order or they're not a church.
I think the Knights of Columbus and the Masonic Temple are -- Masons are close enough to being a religious organization to be exempt under the provisions of the statute.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So the Masons are religious org?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Well, You Honor, I know that everything that they have in the Masons to a larger extent, deals with -- I -- I would say regard in church principles.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, let's take -- let's take lodges like the Elks Lodge and the --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: They have to comply.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- and the Moose and Eagles and lodges of that kind, do they all comply?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.
As a matter of fact, I believe the record will show that the Ladies' Garden Clubs comply too.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All the college fraternities?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: To the best of my knowledge, I don't know.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: It seemed to me with only 517 registering in the year 1959 that that could hardly be so because there were --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, there are --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- I imagine there are many college fraternities --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: As I attempt --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- to be restrained, if you didn't count anything else.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: As I attempted to explain, Your Honor, the registration period for that year had not closed on the date that the court order that the Secretary of State to produce that information.
The organizations that desired to file still had several weeks.
After that total was given within which to file the membership in their organizations and come within compliance, so that figure could not be used at all.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Getting -- I think we have -- well, there's one more question really that comes up.
The question as to whether or not, there was any -- any economic reprisals or intimidation as a result of the publication of these names and lists.
As I've stated, the State here is in rather bad position to prove anything.
The only thing we know about the members are the information that the organizations have filed with us.

As I say however, each organization, N.A.A.C.P. affiliate within the State that did file a membership list for a two consecutive year period, shows that the second year, their membership increased substantially over the first year.
Thus, it's rather hard to say that the filing of the membership acted as a deterrent upon membership because they actually increased after each filing.
Now, there is some evidence given by affidavit to the effect that persons were discriminated against.

The affidavits are very general, a man comes in, we have some several of the gentlemen who were officers in various branches of the N.A.A.C.P. who came in and filed affidavits to the effect that they had been discriminated against.
In order to go behind these affidavits, the State of Louisiana took the deposition of these individuals.
And almost without exception, the testimony elicited from them while under interrogatories and examination, show that these affidavits that had originally filed were no sense correct.
They -- people who had stated that they were discriminated against upon cross-examinations said that nobody ever talked to him about their membership in the organization.

In fact, one gentleman who said he had been discriminated against was drawing an old age pension from the State when he wasn't entitled thereto, he testified that he and his wife who were members in the organization, had never been reproached, nobody had ever discussed the matter with him.
Yet, his affidavit said that he had been discriminated against.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Schuler, why was all these information elicited on affidavit from depositions rather than your testimony?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, because that's the only way the District Court in our district will allow us to try a preliminary injunction suit.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean all preliminary injunction --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- must require an affidavit?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: We have requested on several occasions to try them by other manners and our District Court says that it does not try preliminary injunctions other than by affidavit.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, they -- one newspaper in Coushatta published some for the Red River branch of the N.A.A.C.P.
Generally, I don't believe they were published.

The only fact -- the only way, I was able to derive information as to the number of members in the various organizations on particular years, was to go to the Secretary of State's office and count off the number of members that appeared on the -- on the list in that particular year.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: There is a public record?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Were there any publications by newspapers with others of the memberships of other institutions or associations?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I'll be honest with Your Honor, I don't know.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is it fair to say as a matter of the earlier colloquy that there's nothing in this record to show or had -- was the State reactivated this statute in 1956?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: There --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Other than the general (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I can find nothing in the --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- Attorney General to enforce the law.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I can find nothing in the statutes specifically designated other than the fact that it's a general requirement of law that the Attorney General does this.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Oh, there was a reactivation of the statute --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- dead letter, that's all I was --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That is correct.
It's -- it's not denied or whatsoever.
Now, getting down to -- if we're clear on the facts, the law on the subject I think can be primarily divided into two categories.
While the Court has not done it, it seems to me that your freedoms of association cases are divided into two categories.

The first is the -- what I call the communal right to freedom of association which is the right not to have to produce membership list of an organization and the second is a personal right which keeps a person from having to give information as to his own personal affiliations with organizations.
The first category of cases since it's most appropriate to the matter here today should be discussed first.
There are four cases that this Court has decided previously relevant to this one field.
Now, Bryant versus Zimmerman, N.A.A.C.P. versus Alabama, Bates versus Little Rock and Uphaus versus Wyman.
Now, they're split 50-50 on the effect of the First Amendment upon the production of this list.
Both the Zimmerman case and the Uphaus case required the production whereas, the N.A.A.C.P. and the Bates case do not.
However, I believe there's a great distinction between the case today and the Bates and Alabama cases.
This Court decided in both of those cases that there was no justification whatsoever for the production of the membership list.
In the Alabama case, they said that all the State intended to prove by the production of the list under subpoena duces tecum was business that the N.A.A.C.P. had done within the State.
And the N.A.A.C.P. in its answer admitted that it has done that business.
Therefore, there was absolutely no necessity for the production of the list to prove something that was admitted in the answer.
The second case, the Bates case was a local taxation statute.
In this --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Before we get on with the cases, I'd like to go back a little bit to the fact that it's found by the District Court.
What do you do with the -- there aren't specific finding, were there specific finding --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- that will be most -- extract them from the per curiam opinion, is that right?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, then that these three judges, two of them your local -- Louisiana judges are --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: All three of them are --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All of them, yes, I beg your pardon, all of them.
Page 176 to 179.
They say on page 178, Mr. Schuler, “The documentary evidence submitted by the N.A.A.C.P. shows that some members after exposure as members have been subjected to certain economic reprisal.”
The Court going -- onto say that a large part of the membership of school teachers and after the injunction, every one of them resigned from the N.A.A.C.P.
And the footnote says that after the 1955 injunction, not only did the branches declined a number which might not be significant, but the total membership declined from 13,000 to 6000.
It doesn't quite fit in with the figures that I gathered from you perhaps erroneously.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, the -- those figures are figures submitted by the N.A.A.C.P. from the national headquarters.
We have no way of verifying or -- the figures in any way.
The only figures we submitted were the figures that were available to us, the list that had been filed with the State.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean as they contradicted these figures?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I don't know.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, is there --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: There's no way of telling.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They must have done something that those figures contradict -- according to your figures, you say their membership increased.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Of the figures that are available to us, the membership did increase.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean whether the figures available to you are figures of that the N.A.A.C.P. old and the affiliates submitted.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Although, the declarations against interest if they contradict their own testimony.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, I think that can be reconciled and that I believe the N.A.A.C.P. has alleged they had 40 some affiliates within the State.
Now -- and on the most populous year, only 11 of those affiliates filed.
What happened to the membership of the 29 affiliates that did not file, I'm in no position to guess that conjecture or report to this Court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All I'm suggesting is this that we've got to decide which I have to dispose of the case on the basis of this record.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I understand that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, here's a decision by three judges, locally, all of them has been properly, like -- three -- all three them, local judges and they give me these findings, the practical purposes or the finding, as much so as if they had appendix 1,2,3, enumerated set of findings.
Isn't that true?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Yes, sir, but I don't believe the facts justified the decision of the Court, that's why I'm here.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, there's nothing in the record that contradicts that you say -- you say that the Court didn't allow you to contradict and that's what in effect you're saying.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That's a --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is that what you're saying?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That is entirely correct.
There was no way -- the only contradiction that we were able to achieve was that when affidavits were filed with regard to specific happenings.
We went out to depositions of the parties therein and the depositions of the parties showed that the affidavits filed were incorrect that they had built up large things out of practically nothing.

The records replete with the change of the attitude of witnesses between an affidavit that they filed without cross-examination and what they testified to when they're brought in, put under oath, and under cross-examination, asked questions.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, I haven't -- it was the first time that I'm paging, thus leafing around and just leafing your brief.
Has your brief set forth in deadly parallel columns or in appropriate way that that the record doesn't -- contradicts or at least, just does not justify the conclusions of the forth?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Oh, yes, sir.
My brief certainly does.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where is that?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, I go into the testimony of the various witnesses.
They contradict their testimony on pages 27 through 32 of my brief.
This just picks out excerpts, but I don't believe these excerpts are out of context.
I believe that out of the record itself, you can see that they really show the true attitude of the situation at the time that they could --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did you as -- as the record -- is the State argued before these three judges, before the District Court that the only way -- the only way to search the accuracy of these allegations or affidavits would be to put witnesses on the stand and have them cross-examined in the hearing of the judges?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where is that in the record?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor that that is not taken down in the record.
There was no argument in the record at all.
Actually, a lot of the witnesses --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You had no argument at all?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Well, I say we had argument -- oral argument on --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did you -- did you put the point you've just put to this Court that that court, namely that this case may well do.
You haven't challenged the relevance of the issue of discrimination resulting from the requirement of filing the report, do you?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, may I say --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Suppose -- just answer that if you -- you couldn't have.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Yes, we -- we charged that the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, but if -- if -- did you deny the relevance -- did you say that it doesn't make any difference even as a result of filing, they would be discriminated?
Do you make that -- take that position or do you take that (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: No, sir.
We -- very -- as much as we could, we attempted to controvert all testimony that had been introduced.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did you thereby acknowledge the relevance of their claim that this resulted in unfair discrimination against them?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: No, I didn't acknowledge that.
No, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I did not acknowledge --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't mean the proof of it, but the relevance.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I deny both.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Alright, then you say that even if you could prove that they were right or prove that they were wrong, doesn't make any difference, is that what you're saying?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: To -- to a --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Are you taking that position here?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, it's hard to take a definite position because as this Court has held so many times, you have to weigh and balance --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, but --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: -- the particular effects.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm asking you is that on a -- a factor to be balanced?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Oh, it's going to have to be balanced.
Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Alright.
Then you -- then you admit the relevance?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: It's relevant.
Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Alright.
Now, did you then say to the Court in an appropriate way that since this is an issue properly before the Court, you must have opportunity to disprove the establishment of that issue?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, that was taken up with all three judges and the ruling on that was this was only a hearing on a preliminary injunction, that it was only necessary that the defendant or that the plaintiffs herein show a prima facie case.
That if the question of intimidation became a real issue that we always had the right to go back on the permanent injunction and try it by oral testimony.
That's not only the ruling on this case.
That's the ruling on every case of this nature we have tried in the State for the past five years.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, never mind all the other cases.
In this case, was the ruling of the Court that for purposes of a preliminary injunction, will take as proof, allegations in an affidavit.
Is that the position of the Court?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, that is not only the ruling of the Court.
It is the rules of the Court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean formulated rules.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did you then say, very well, we will try to show those trials on the permanent injunction?
Have you made that endeavor?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: No, sir, we have not, Your Honor, because we felt that even though we were not allowed to cross-examination -- cross-examine the witnesses in the State on the stand at the time the hearing went on, we went further, we went out, went 300 and somewhat miles to Shreveport to locate witnesses who made affidavits for the other end of the State and took oral deposition from them and put those in the record.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Let's -- let's see if you and I can come to an issue.

As I understand you, your claim is that under the rules of the District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana, claims made by a plaintiff seeking a temporary injunction will be taking as established for purposes of granting the temporary injunction.
Is that right?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: No, sir.
I say they are taken solely by affidavit.
There's no oral testimony.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, I know, but in anything they say in an affidavit will be accepted as true, is that it?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Unless it is contradicted in a -- other affidavit then the court weighs the two.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you say in this case, you weren't in a position to contradict except through cross-examination and examination.
Is that right?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: And affidavits of our own.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, I know, but those do not adequately enable you to disprove the allegation.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: No, sir, they do not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And so really, your case down here comes to the validity of the District of the Eastern District to have such a rule, is that it?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: It does.
If this Court is -- if this Court will decide that the -- it is necessary to have intimidation in order to have the First Amendment apply herein.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you just said that you yourself regarded as relevant, as relevant that discrimination follows the disclosure in the report, didn't you?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I think it's relevant then.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Alright.
Well, if it's an issue, it's relevant then you ought to be allowed to -- to meet the issue.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, there's one other issue that I'd like to get to very quickly.
That is the second part of our statute which requires that the organizations filed a list of their officers.
In our State, there is no requirement whatsoever that these organizations register with the State in any matter shall perform.
In other words, you can start an organization, it can operate and other than this statute, you have no idea who the officers are, who the members are or anything about the organization whatsoever.

We feel that even under all the decisions of this Court, including Bates case and Alabama case that we have a perfect right to know who the officers of the national and affiliate organizations are and that this information is not protected at all by the First Amendment and a right of association.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: How about the -- or are you going to get to the second statute involved?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: The second statute, I will get to -- that I could've gotten to it a lot better if we had an interpretation by our own state court.

The local court down in New Orleans is, I -- I'm talking about the federal court, decided that the statute was unconstitutional because it placed a burden upon people in the State of Louisiana that they had no way of performing, that is tell what member -- what organizations other people belong to.
Well, I think the statute is susceptible of that interpretation.
I believe it's also susceptible of a constitutional interpretation.
The statute makes no distinction as to who should file the list.

I say if our Court had to determine that statute, they would say that the individuals who were the officers of the national association would have to make those affidavits which would in turn be filed by the local organization as a prerequisite to doing business in the State.

Now, that would be my interpretation of it and I think it would run right along the lines of the noncommunist affidavits that you have to file in order to do business with the National Labor Relations Board.
But as I say, since our state court never had the possibility of interpreting the statute, that's only -- an interpretation I believe could be placed on it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is that Act 260 --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: That is Act 260 of 1958.
That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I understood that the -- from the opinion here that the Attorney General conceded that the State was not interested in pressing the argument as the constitutionality of the --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: I believe the Court was a little liberal on -- with the words of the Attorney General.

I believe I argued that matter myself and what I told the Court was that there are absolutely no statutes similar or exactly similar to our statute herein and that frankly, I just couldn't give them any law to sustain the statute and that I didn't care to -- that I couldn't argue it any further.
As I say, primarily, I was interested in the other one.
But as I say, this statute, I did not concede the constitutionality of it or the unconstitutionality.
In fact, I'm prohibited by law from so doing within the State.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you about the other statement on page 178?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Yes, sir, certainly.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) Mr. Justice Frankfurter asked you about where they said that one ground that they found in Louisiana statute, a lot of teachers belong to the organization.
The Louisiana statutes denied an employment to them, if they believed in integration of the racism in public schools.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, there, I would say, are probably three answers to that.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was there such a statute?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: There was such a statute on the books.
Number one, I believe it was declared unconstitutional in a previous Court of Appeal decision case, LSU -- Ludley versus Louisiana State University.
Second, the statute has never been enforced either before or after the Ludley decision and third of all, unlike the school boards in --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But how could they know it wouldn't be enforced, you waited 25 years to enforce it but --

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, as I say, I believe it was declared unconstitutional in the Ludley versus LSU case.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, they -- they couldn't be assumed to know that it was unconstitutional, could they?

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Their names were exposed.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor and may I get to the third point --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: -- unlike Shelton versus Tucker, the teachers are not hired on a yearly basis.
They have teachers' tenure and in event, this tenure is attempted to be interrupted.

They have a hearing before the Board, court proceedings which could eventually come all the way up to this Court for a determination of their rights under this particular statute and determine the constitutionality thereof.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That would be a pretty heavy price to pay to belong to an organization.

turn.speaker: william_pschuler
turn.label: Mr. William P.schuler
turn.text: Your Honor, that -- all I'm doing on that is attempting to ferret out the distinction between the case of Shelton versus Tucker and the cases handed down this Monday with regard to membership in the bar associations of our various states.
Thank you, Your Honors.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Carter.

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: If the Court please, I -- I think that at least in terms of -- of the interpretation of the facts that Mr. Schuler and I are somewhat at odds and if -- with your permission, I will spend some time in attempting to explain what I concede to be the facts in this case, in respect to its present posture.
In 1924, as Mr. Schuler indicated, this statute which is the membership filing statute, the old statute, was enacted.
It apparently accomplished this purpose and laid on it until 1956.

In 1956, the Attorney General LeBlanc brought action in the state court against the N.A.A.C.P. charging that it had failed to comply with the statute which require the filing of membership list and therefore that the organization should be dissolved.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: When they say brought actions, Mr. Carter, was there any allegation that this failure followed a demand for filing?

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It was just an action --

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: There was no demand.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- out of the blue of which --

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- N.A.A.C.P of nothing?

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: Yes, that's right.
This -- this action was filed, there was no demand that any list to be filed, no demand that there'd be any compliance with this law.
Now, that statute -- of rather that case was -- was then in the state courts of East Baton Rouge.
We filed a petition to remove the case to the federal court.
While this -- we -- although, we had complied with 44 -- 40 -- 1446, the state court nonetheless, proceeded to hear the case and to issue an injunction against the operation of the organization.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, does the State, N.A.A.C.P. or one the -- one of the local branches or the national or what?

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: Well, they issued it against -- they've dissolved all N.A.A.C.P. operation and functioning in the State, prohibited until we had complied with the -- with the --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Who were the parties?

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: -- with the organization.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Who -- who was the defendant?

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: The defendants were -- were the New York Corporation and several of the officers and -- and members and -- and employees that worked in -- in Louisiana.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What is the state organization, Mr. Carter?

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: Well, there are -- doesn't -- that there are several branches.
There about -- there were in 1955, some 65 branches which were in New Orleans and various (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, they are branches of the New York Corporation or --

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: They are unincorporated affiliates of the N.A.A.C.P. in New York.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did the N.A.A.C.P. , what kind of a corporation is it?

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: It's a -- it's a membership corporation --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: New York Corporation.

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: A New York Corporation.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, in order to do business in Louisiana, does it have to get a permission from the circuit?

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: No, sir.
We do not and --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You do not.

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: This is conceded.
You don't --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: We -- we do not have to file any or do -- do anything or to do business in Louisiana.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: We know statute like the Alabama statute.

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: That's right.
In fact I, if I'm not mistaken, I think this is conceded in -- in the answer which the Attorney General had spoken.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, in addition to these 65 affiliates, Mr. Carter, is there some supervening state organization?

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: There is a -- an organization called the -- the Louisiana State Conference of N.A.A.C.P. branches, which is merely a -- an overall organization which seeks to carry out on the statewide basis, the -- the activities of these 65 branches.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's not a corporation, is it?

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: That none of -- none of the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Just way of connecting together these loose bodies.

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: That's right.
Well, the only corporation involved in the N.A.A.C.P. is the New York Corporation.
All the other affiliates aren't corporation.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But the injunction sought in the state courts would have or whatever the relief was by injunction or otherwise, would've dissolved all of the affiliates, is that it?

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: All the affiliates.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And this conference, state conference.

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: All affiliates, any kind of any N.A.A.C.P. activity was prohibited by this injunction.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Was the -- was the suit to dissolve these collectives or to make them file reports or both, which was it?

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: The suit was to dissolve them until they had filed (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Until but the purpose was to get filings.

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: So that judgment was void wasn't it, Mr. Carter?

turn.speaker: robert_lcarter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L.carter
turn.text: That judgment was -- was declared void in a -- on appeal on the grounds that it had -- it had come after removal had been affected and therefore was in violation of 1446.
Now, at that point, we -- we went in -- back into the federal court to seek to enjoin the state proceedings and the proceeding further with the case.
Federal court indicated that it could not, even though it agreed with us that the State had -- that the state court was incorrect.
That it could not do anything about this, that we had to prosecute in our -- our appeal into the Louisiana courts in which we did.
Now, after the Louisiana Court of Appeals ruled that the judgment was void and what had been done was void, nothing was done about this -- this case that had been removed.
It stayed in the courts until 1958, this new statute which required the filing of affidavits was enacted.
